data.title: Fueling - What's Holding You Back from Better?
data.description: Do you know you could be fueling better, but don't know where to start? If you're following a training plan and working hard, but still aren't achieving the gains you're hoping for (or think you deserve), nutrition—and how it's timed relative to the stage

asset.author: Vega
asset.hookText:
Do you know you could be fueling better, but don't know where to start? If you're following a training plan and working hard, but still aren't achieving the gains you're hoping for (or think you deserve), nutrition—and how it's timed relative to the stages of your workout—could be the missing piece

When you eat is just as important as what you eat

Performance nutrition should play a significant role in your training routine. Your body has specific nutritional needs before, during and after your workout. Before you work out, your body needs fuel. It can use a balance of high- and low-glycemic carbs. During your workout, carbs also help you go the distance. Refueling every 45 minutes with easily digested carbs is recommended. 

Every athlete is unique, so it's important that you listen to your body, as your fuel needs can change over time and vary depending on the duration and intensity of your workout. After your workout, your body needs to replenish and repair. Replenish muscle glycogen with a 4-to-1 ratio of carbs-to-protein within a 20 minute window. Then repair and build muscles with clean, plant-based protein and BCAAs within 45 minutes of your workout (be sure to space your protein at least 20 minutes after your 4-to-1 replenishment for best results). 

To learn more about the Vega Sport System—and products that could benefit training at all stages of your workout—check out www.VegaSport.com

data.title: Overtraining - What's Holding You Back from Better?
data.description:
Stuck on a plateau no matter how hard you train? If you're training more and more and more, and you're not getting any closer to your goals, you might have reached a plateau from overtraining.

Train less, recover more

It's possible to train too much. Wh

asset.author: Vega
asset.hookText:
Stuck on a plateau no matter how hard you train? If you're training more and more and more, and you're not getting any closer to your goals, you might have reached a plateau from overtraining.

Train less, recover more

It's possible to train too much. While it may seem counter-intuitive, achieving more might mean training less and recovering more. Taking a rest day could get you closer to your goals than pushing through. It's also important to focus on active recovery techniques such as cooling down, stretching and foam rolling. 

Recovery nutrition 

If you've pushed yourself too hard, too often, start focusing on proactive post-workout replenishment. In the first 20 minutes after your workout, consume a 4-to-1 ratio of carbs-to-protein. This ratio replenishes muscle glycogen faster than carbs alone for your next workout. To support muscle repair, post-workout protein and BCAAs provides the materials your body needs to come back stronger. Time your post-workout protein at least 20 minutes after supplementing (or eating) your 4-to-1 carb-to-protein.

To learn how the Vega Sport Nutrition System supports recovery, and benefits your training, check out VegaSport.com.

data.title: Muscle Soreness - What's Holding You Back from Better?
data.description: Ready to train again, but still sore from yesterday's workout? Feeling stiff and sore after a good workout can be satisfying—it's a natural part of getting stronger. However, the faster (and more effectively) you recover between workouts, the faster you c

asset.author: Vega
asset.hookText:
Ready to train again, but still sore from yesterday's workout? Feeling stiff and sore after a good workout can be satisfying—it's a natural part of getting stronger. However, the faster (and more effectively) you recover between workouts, the faster you can train again. And the faster you can make gains.

Training gains without pain

Reducing muscle soreness can start even before you work out. Don't underestimate the value of warming up with active stretching. Focus on cooling down, stretching, and foam rolling after your workout. If you have problematic areas—like knees—invest training time in strengthening the supporting muscles around the area.

Reduce inflammation to reduce muscle soreness 

Quality nutrition is a powerful strategy for speeding recovery. Often muscle soreness is caused by inflammation. Plant-based foods that are rich in antioxidants and healthy fats to support inflammation management. Natural herbs and supplements can also help with inflammation. Curcumin—the active component of turmeric—is a powerful inflammation fighter. 

To learn how the Vega Sport Nutrition System supports all stages of your workout, check out VegaSport.com.

data.title: Body Composition - What's Holding You Back from Better?
data.description: If you want to go faster and farther, you'll want to work on getting stronger and leaner. An athlete's strength-to-weight ratio is a major factor in how fast—and how far—they can go. By increasing your strength-to-weight ratio, you can take your performan

asset.author: Vega
asset.hookText:
If you want to go faster and farther, you'll want to work on getting stronger and leaner. An athlete's strength-to-weight ratio is a major factor in how fast—and how far—they can go. By increasing your strength-to-weight ratio, you can take your performance to the next level.

Training to Get Stronger and Leaner 

Even if you're an endurance athlete, it's important to cross-train with weights and High Intensity Interval Training (HIIT). Your goal is not to add bulk but to improve your strength level andyour ratio of lean muscle to body fat. Both weight training and HIIT complement endurance training to build a leaner, stronger body that can go faster and farther. 

Eating to Get Stronger and Leaner

If you're eating a clean, plant-based diet you are able to maximize your nutrition for relatively few calories. Dietary protein supports the development of lean muscle when combined with strength training, and the timing of protein after your workout is crucial. You may be worried about getting enough protein with your increased cross-training. Don't worry—it's easy to combine carbs with protein in a 4-to-1 carb-to-protein ratio immediately after a workout then follow with protein and BCAAs at least 20 minutes later (45 minutes post-workout).

To learn how the Vega Sport Nutrition System supports recovery, and benefits your training, check out VegaSport.com.

data.title: Stamina - What's Holding You Back from Better?
data.description:
Your mind is 100% there, but your body just can't go the distance you want it to. If you've been fueling sufficiently, and you're still struggling to go the distance, you're likely dealing with insufficient endurance or stamina. 

Training to build up sta

asset.author: Vega
asset.hookText:
Your mind is 100% there, but your body just can't go the distance you want it to. If you've been fueling sufficiently, and you're still struggling to go the distance, you're likely dealing with insufficient endurance or stamina. 

Training to build up stamina

If you're working on a new distance goal (e.g., you're graduating from half-marathons to full marathons), you'll need to build up stamina. By increasing both endurance and strength you'll improve stamina. The first half of stamina training is to put in the days and train at a lower intensity for longer time. Gradual increases are the most effective way to increase endurance. Aim for a 10% increase in mileage or duration per week. The second half of stamina training is to cross-train for strength. 

Caffeine for stamina 

Support your endurance training with a little pre-workout caffeine—known for enhancing endurance performance. Choose a holistic stimulant such as green tea or yerba maté.
To learn how the Vega Sport Nutrition System supports all stages of your workout, check out VegaSport.com.

data.title: Motivation - What's Holding You Back From Better?
data.description: Still love your sport, but feel like you have to push yourself out the door to train these days? The daily grind of training can affect even the most dedicated athletes. Whether you've hit a training plateau, are mentally and physically exhausted, or sick

asset.author: Vega
asset.hookText:
Still love your sport, but feel like you have to push yourself out the door to train these days? The daily grind of training can affect even the most dedicated athletes. Whether you've hit a training plateau, are mentally and physically exhausted, or sick of the weather, it's normal to need an extra boost of motivation every now and again. 

Boost motivation with training

Sometimes a simple change in routine can shake you out of a rut. Whether you switch up the distance, intensity, time of day, duration or frequency, cross-training to switch your pattern can result in motivation gains. It also never hurts to grab a buddy to be accountable to.

Boost motivation with caffeine

Caffeine is a well-known performance enhancer. Not only does it support endurance, but it also helps with mental focus. If you're struggling to get in the zone, a little caffeine could be just the boost you need to get out the door

To learn how the Vega Sport Nutrition System supports all stages of your workout to benefit performance, check out VegaSport.com.

data.title: Muscle Burn - What's Holding You Back from Better?
data.description: Have your muscles ever burned so badly you had to stop mid-workout? You likely know that muscle burn is caused by lactic acid buildup. Usually we think of lactic acid as a bad thing (it burns—and it can stop you in your tracks!) but you can actually think

asset.author: Vega
asset.hookText:
Have your muscles ever burned so badly you had to stop mid-workout? You likely know that muscle burn is caused by lactic acid buildup. Usually we think of lactic acid as a bad thing (it burns—and it can stop you in your tracks!) but you can actually think of it as stored energy.

During aerobic exercise your body makes energy from stored glycogen or consumed glucose and oxygen. During an all-out sprint (anaerobic exercise) your body has to switch paths and makes lactic acid (in the absence of oxygen). Although it burns, once your pace slows (and oxygen returns), your body is able to reconvert energy stored as lactic acid into fuel.  

Train to increase your lactate threshold 

The only way to completely avoid the burn of lactic acid is to avoid anaerobic activities that bring it on. But best way to decrease the burn is to increase your lactate threshold. Your lactate threshold is the point at which your body has to produce lactic acid. You can postpone this burn with high-intensity pace runs or fartliks.

Nutrition to decrease muscle burn 

Lactic acid is more likely to affect you if you're dehydrated. It's easier for your body to cope with the pH change from lactic acid— and to clear away waste—when you're adequately hydrated. Ensure you're hydrated with more than water. Replenish important electrolytes: sodium, potassium, magnesium, chloride.

To learn how the Vega Sport Nutrition System can support you mid-workout, check out VegaSport.com.

data.title: Hitting a Wall - What's Holding You Back from Better?
data.description: Most endurance athletes have felt—and still fear—the feeling of running on fumes and bonking mid-workout. If you've suffered from a drastic drop in energy levels, impaired decision making, and had your muscles suddenly stop listening, you know what it mea

asset.author: Vega
asset.hookText:
Most endurance athletes have felt—and still fear—the feeling of running on fumes and bonking mid-workout. If you've suffered from a drastic drop in energy levels, impaired decision making, and had your muscles suddenly stop listening, you know what it means to bonk or hit the wall. Generally, this is caused by a complete depletion of stored glucose—in the form of muscle glycogen and a subsequent drop in blood sugar, bringing you to a complete halt. 

Fueling to avoid the wall 

If you've eaten well and recovered between workouts, you have about an hour of stored glycogen. Therefore, exercise beyond one hour requires additional fuel to avoid bonking. Carbohydrates are your body's preferred choice of fuel. The higher your exercise intensity, the greater your need for carbs.  As a general rule, consume easily-digested carbs every 45 minutes. Ease of digestion is important during activity so blood flow is not diverted away from your limbs to your digestive system.

To learn how the Vega Sport Nutrition System can support you before, during and after your workout, visit VegaSport.com.
